@docroland @PAINKILLS2 @TrueBennett @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain Opioid prescribing is almost at 20 year lows in the US though. Oxycontin was marketed as

@Alberta_Pain @speakingabtpain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain Most of the studies on the effects of opioids seem to exclude patients that benefit the most from LTOT. If you really can't follow the patients who benefit (preferably for years), it's hard to to accurately assess both benefits and harms. Dr. Tennant's might be the only study.

@docroland @TrueBennett @PAINKILLS2 @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain All we're saying is, the claim "opioids don't appear to help chronic pain" isn't adequately supported by data, if the data averages a heterogeneous group.

If 99 people get 0 pain reduction, and one person gets 10, the average is the same as if 100 people got .1 each.

@docroland @ReeseSTyrell @TrueBennett @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain Billions of tablets being spread out through what size of an area? If they sent a billion tablets to New York City, how many tablets would every person in New York get? I can see the point of a billion went to an area with a population of 10k, that would be insane.

@ReeseSTyrell @TrueBennett @PAINKILLS2 @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain Again, I‚Äôm not saying they don‚Äôt help a small subset of people. That has been my own anecdotal experience. But we‚Äôre talking about billions of tablets. For years. That‚Äôs not a small subset.

@PAINKILLS2 @TrueBennett @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain We were lied to and manipulated, for years. It continues to be a problem. #opioidcrisis

@docroland @TrueBennett @PAINKILLS2 @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain I hypothesize the data on opioids would show different results between: 1) a group of patients who have just been diagnosed with chronic pain and haven't tried much yet, and 2) a group of patients who have not improved after engaging in 40+ alternative protocols.

@docroland @TrueBennett @PAINKILLS2 @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain I am advocating for research to answer the question "are opioids helpful for management of chronic pain in certain individual patients who have not improved with other protocols?" 

That research question, to my knowledge, has not been asked (yet).

@docroland @TrueBennett @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain The main argument people go to first about opioids is they cause massive withdrawals when ceased. I cant help but wonder why any physician would prescribe these meds as "standard of care" for chronic pain if there arent any studies that back it up? I mean,  hey, drs are so smart

@TrueBennett @ReeseSTyrell @PAINKILLS2 @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain But to be clear, do you have research to support long term opioids for the management of chronic pain?

If you‚Äôre advocating for its use, you must have data to support that, right?
@PAINKILLS2 @TrueBennett @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain Yes. It does. What‚Äôs your point?
@docroland @TrueBennett @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain Stopping daily coffee intake causes withdrawal......

@docroland @TrueBennett @PAINKILLS2 @Alberta_Pain @StefanKertesz @UABNews @drrobbietee @guyfelicella @BCCSU @wcaforum @CAMHnews @PainBC @talks_pain I don't see where anyone made a claim about "most patients."

Data I've seen supports the hypothesis that opioids are not helpful for most people, but life-restoring for a few as last resort. Haven't seen this directly tested, but I've never seen data inconsistent with it either.
